revision.text:
{{about|applications in pedagogy and psychology|a broader coverage|Socratic method|the literary genre|Socratic dialogue}} {{socrates}}
'''Socratic questioning''' (or '''Socratic [[maieutics]]''')<ref>Jacques Brunschwig, Geoffrey Ernest Richard Lloyd (eds), [https://books.google.com/books?id=AXl9j4n2iP4C&dq= ''A Guide to Greek Thought: Major Figures and Trends''], Harvard University Press, 2003, p. 233.</ref> was named after [[Socrates]], who was a philosopher in c. 470 BCE–c. 399 BCE<ref>{{cite web|title=Socrates Biography|url=https://www.biography.com/people/socrates-9488126|website=The Biography.com website|publisher=A&E Television Networks|accessdate=March 31, 2018}}</ref>. Socrates utilized an educational method that focused on discovering answers by asking questions from his students. Socrates believed that "the disciplined practice of thoughtful questioning enables the scholar/student to examine ideas and be able to determine the validity of those ideas" <ref>{{cite web|title=What is Socratic Questioning|url=https://serc.carleton.edu/introgeo/socratic/second.html|website=Starting Point - Teaching Entry Level Geoscience|publisher=Carleton College|accessdate=March 31, 2018}}</ref>. [[Plato]], a student of Socrates, described this rigorous method of teaching to explain that the teacher assumes an ignorant mindset in order to compel the student to assume the highest level of knowledge <ref>{{cite web|title=What is Socratic Questioning|url=https://serc.carleton.edu/introgeo/socratic/second.html|website=Starting Point - Teaching Entry Level Geoscience|publisher=Carleton College|accessdate=March 31, 2018}}</ref>. Thus, a student has the ability to acknowledge contradictions, recreate inaccurate or unfinished ideas and critically determine necessary thought.
Socratic questioning is a form of disciplined [[question]]ing that can be used to pursue [[thought]] in many directions and for many purposes, including: to explore complex ideas, to get to the [[truth]] of things, to open up issues and problems, to uncover assumptions, to analyze concepts, to distinguish what we know from what we do not know, to follow out [[logical consequence]]s of thought or to control discussions. Socratic questioning is based on the foundation that thinking has structured logic, and allows underlying thoughts to be questioned.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Paul|first1=Richard|last2=Binker|first2=A.J.|title=Critical Thinking: What Every Person Needs To Survive in a Rapidly Changing World|date=1990|publisher=Foundation for Critical Thinking|isbn=0-944583-08-3|page=360}}</ref> The key to distinguishing Socratic questioning from questioning ''per se'' is that Socratic questioning is systematic, disciplined, deep and usually focuses on fundamental concepts, principles, theories, issues or problems.
Socratic questioning is referred to in [[teaching]], and has gained currency as a concept in [[education]], particularly in the past two decades.{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} Teachers, students, or anyone interested in probing thinking at a deep level can construct Socratic questions and engage in these questions.<ref>Paul, R. and Elder, L. (2006). ''The Art of Socratic Questioning''. Dillon Beach, CA: Foundation for Critical Thinking.</ref> Socratic questioning and its variants have also been extensively used in psychotherapy.
== Pedagogy == When teachers use Socratic questioning in teaching, their purpose may be to probe student thinking, to determine the extent of student knowledge on a given topic, issue or subject, to model Socratic questioning for students or to help students analyze a concept or line of reasoning. It is suggested that students should learn the discipline of Socratic questioning so that they begin to use it in reasoning through complex issues, in understanding and assessing the thinking of others and in following-out the implications of what they and others think. In fact, Socrates himself thought that questioning was the only defensible form of teaching.
In teaching, teachers can use Socratic questioning for at least two purposes: * To deeply probe student thinking, to help students begin to distinguish what they know or understand from what they do not know or understand (and to help them develop intellectual humility in the process). * To foster students' abilities to ask Socratic questions, to help students acquire the powerful tools of Socratic dialogue, so that they can use these tools in everyday life (in questioning themselves and others). To this end, teachers can model the questioning strategies they want students to emulate and employ. Moreover, teachers need to directly teach students how to construct and ask deep questions. Beyond that, students need practice to improve their questioning abilities.
Socratic questioning illuminates the importance of questioning in learning. This includes differentiating between systematic and fragmented thinking, while forcing individuals to understand the root of their knowledge and ideas. Educators who support the use of Socratic Questioning in educational settings argue that it helps students become active and independent learners. Examples of Socratic questions that are used for students in educational settings: <ref>'[https://web.archive.org/web/20101024112450/http://osiriseducational.co.uk/outstandingteaching/news/questions-questions-questions/ Outstanding Teaching]'. UK.</ref>{{Unreliable source?|date=March 2012}} # Getting students to clarify their thinking and explore the origin of their thinking #: ''e.g''., 'Why do you say that?', 'Could you explain further?' # Challenging students about [[:wikt:assumption|assumption]]s #: ''e.g''., 'Is this always the case?', 'Why do you think that this assumption holds here?' # Providing [[evidence]] as a basis for [[argument]]s #: ''e.g''., 'Why do you say that?', 'Is there reason to doubt this evidence?' # Discovering alternative viewpoints and perspectives and conflicts between [[Main contention|contention]]s #: ''e.g''., 'What is the counter-argument?', 'Can/did anyone see this another way?' # Exploring [[:wikt:implication|implication]]s and [[:wikt:consequence|consequence]]s #: ''e.g''., 'But if...happened, what else would result?', 'How does...affect...?' # Questioning the question #: ''e.g''., 'Why do you think that I asked that question?', 'Why was that question important?', 'Which of your questions turned out to be the most useful?'
== Socratic questioning and critical thinking ==
The art of Socratic questioning is intimately connected with [[critical thinking]] because the art of questioning is important to excellence of thought. Socrates argued for the necessity of probing individual knowledge, and acknowledging what one may not know or understand. Critical thinking has the goal of reflective thinking that focuses on what should be believed or done about a topic.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ennis|first1=Robert|title=Developing Minds: A Resource Book for Teaching Thinking, 3rd Edition|date=2011}}</ref> Socratic questioning adds another level of thought to critical thinking, by focusing on extracting depth, interest and assessing the truth or plausibility of thought. Socrates argued that a lack of knowledge is not bad, but students must strive to make known what they don't know through the means of a form of critical thinking.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sofos|first1=Manolis|title=Critical Thinking: A Historical Overview|journal=Thinking for Career Practical Approach|issue=2|pages=1-5}}</ref>
Critical thinking and Socratic questioning both seek meaning and truth. Critical thinking provides the rational tools to monitor, assess, and perhaps reconstitute or re-direct our thinking and action. This is what educational reformer [[John Dewey]] described as ''reflective inquiry'': "in which the thinker turns a subject over in the mind, giving it serious and consecutive consideration."<ref name=Holden>{{cite journal|last1=Holden|first1=James|title=Inquiry and the Literary Text: Constructing Discussions in the English Classroom. Classroom Practices in Teaching English.|journal=Classroom Practices in Teaching English|date=2002|volume=32|page=9|url=http://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/ED471390.pdf|accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> Socratic questioning is an explicit focus on framing self-directed, disciplined questions to achieve that goal.
The technique of questioning or leading discussion is spontaneous, exploratory, and issue-specific.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Van Aswegen|first=EJ|last2=Brink|first2=HIL|last3=Steyn|first3=PJN|date=November 2011|title=Application and evaluation of a combination of socratic and learning through discussion techniques|url=|journal=Curtionis|volume=24|issue=4|pages=68–77|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> The Socratic educator listens to the viewpoints of the student and considers the alternative points of view.<ref name=":0" /> It is necessary to teach students to sift through all the information, form a connection to prior knowledge, and transform the data to new knowledge in a thoughtful way.<ref name=":0" />
It has been proposed in different studies that the "level of thinking that occurs is influenced by the level of questions asked".<ref name="Yang 2010">{{cite journal|last1=Yang|first1=Ya-Ting|last2=Newby|first2=Timothy|last3=Bill|first3=Robert|title=Using Socratic Questioning to Promote Critical Thinking Skills Through Asynchronous Discussion Forums in Distance Learning Environments|journal=The American Journal of Distance Education|date=January 7, 2010|volume=19|issue=3|page=164|doi=10.1207/s15389286ajde1903_4}}</ref> Thus, utilizing the knowledge that students don't know stimulates their ability to ask more complex questions. This requires educators to create active learning environments that promote and value the role of critical thinking, mobilizing their ability to form complex thoughts and questions.<ref name="Yang 2010" />
== Psychology == Socratic questioning has also been used in [[psychotherapy]], most notably as a [[cognitive restructuring]] technique in [[classical Adlerian psychotherapy]], [[logotherapy]], [[rational emotive behavior therapy]], [[cognitive therapy]], and [[logic-based therapy]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Clark |first1=Gavin I. |last2=Egan |first2=Sarah J. |date=December 2015 |title=The Socratic method in cognitive behavioural therapy: a narrative review |journal=Cognitive Therapy and Research |volume=39 |issue=6 |pages=863–879 |doi=10.1007/s10608-015-9707-3}}</ref> The purpose is to help uncover the assumptions and evidence that underpin people's thoughts in respect of problems. A set of Socratic questions in cognitive therapy aim to deal with automatic thoughts that distress the patient:<ref name="Beck1995">{{cite book|author=Judith S. Beck|title=Cognitive Therapy: Basics and Beyond|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GHVIpQMZf-EC&pg=PA109|accessdate=25 May 2011|year=1995|publisher=Guilford Press|isbn=978-0-89862-847-0|pages=109}}</ref> # Revealing the issue: 'What evidence supports this idea? And what evidence is against its being true?' # Conceiving reasonable alternatives: 'What might be another explanation or viewpoint of the situation? Why else did it happen?' # Examining various potential consequences: 'What are worst, best, bearable and most realistic outcomes?' # Evaluate those consequences: 'What's the effect of thinking or believing this? What could be the effect of thinking differently and no longer holding onto this belief?' # [[Distancing (psychology)|Distancing]]: 'Imagine a specific friend/family member in the same situation or if they viewed the situation this way, what would I tell them?'
Careful use of Socratic questioning enables a therapist to challenge recurring or isolated instances of a person's illogical thinking while maintaining an open position that respects the internal logic to even the most seemingly illogical thoughts.
==See also== {{Div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Argument map]] * [[Argumentation theory]] * [[Critical thinking]] * [[Cross-examination]] * [[Inquiry]] * [[Intellectual virtue]] * [[Interrogation]] * [[Issue map]] * {{section link|Meno|Dialogue with Meno's slave}} {{Div col end}}
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.comment: /* Child abuse unethical interviews */ remove lie by omission. Her methods were at odds with memory psychology research, and her incompetence led to decade-long jailing of innocent people.
revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist |image = |image_size = 150px | name = Susan J. Kelley, Ph.D. |birth_date = |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |residence = [[Georgia, United States]] |nationality = [[United States|American]] |field = [[psychology]], [[child abuse]], [[nursing]] |work_institution = [[Georgia State University]] |alma_mater = [[Boston College]]
[[Boston University]] |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = [[Fells Acres Day Care Center preschool trial]] |author_abbreviation_bot = |author_abbreviation_zoo = |prizes = [[International Cultic Studies Association|ICSA's]] John G. Clark Award for Distinguished Scholarship in Cultic Studies
American Journal of Nursing Book of the Year Award |religion = |footnotes = }} '''Susan J. Kelley''' is the former Dean of the College of Health and Human Sciences at [[Georgia State University]]. She is also currently a Professor of Nursing and the Director of the National Center on Grandparents Raising Grandchildren, and founder and director of Project Healthy Grandparents, at Georgia State University.[http://chhs.gsu.edu/nationalcenter/staff.html Our Faculty & Staff] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20050717013107/http://chhs.gsu.edu/nationalcenter/staff.html |date=2005-07-17 }}, National Center on Grandparents Raising Grandchildren, [[Georgia State University]], retrieved 1/9/07. ==Education== Kelley received her [[Bachelor of Science in Nursing]] from [[Boston University]], 1977, followed by a [[Master of Science in Nursing]] in 1982. She was awarded a [[Ph.D.]] in [[developmental psychology]] from [[Boston College]] in 1988. ==Career== Prior to her current positions, Kelley had previously served as Chairperson and Professor, Department of Maternal-Child Health [[Nursing]] at [[Boston College]]. She was also the Director of [[Nursing education]] at [[Massachusetts]] [[Emergency Medical Services]] and a [[Child health nursing|pediatric nurse]] at [[Columbia Presbyterian Hospital]], and [[Boston City Hospital]].[http://chhs.gsu.edu/nursing/fac_prof_listing.asp Susan J. Kelley, PhD, RN, FAAN] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20040808090718/http://chhs.gsu.edu/nursing/fac_prof_listing.asp |date=2004-08-08 }}, Faculty Profiles, Byrdine F. Lewis School of Nursing She has also served as a guest lecturer at [[George Mason University]].[http://classweb.gmu.edu/rfeeg/ichna/day5.html Sexual Victimization of Young Innocents: An Epidemic] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061221115431/http://classweb.gmu.edu/rfeeg/ichna/day5.html |date=2006-12-21 }}, Susan J. Kelley, PhD, RN, FAAN, [[George Mason University]] In 2000, Kelley served on the Task Force for International Child Health Nursing Alliance.[http://classweb.gmu.edu/rfeeg/ichna/scap.html Steering Committee and Participants of Child Health 2000] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070203021035/http://classweb.gmu.edu/rfeeg/ichna/scap.html |date=2007-02-03 }}, Task Force for International Child Health Nursing Alliance (ICHNA), Dr. Susan J. Kelley. She is a reviewer for the [[academic journal]] ''Nursing Research'', as part of their [[peer review]] process.[http://www.nursing-research-editor.com/reviewers/index.php Current reviewers] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061226224052/http://www.nursing-research-editor.com/reviewers/index.php |date=2006-12-26 }}, ''Nursing Research'', [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]], retrieved 1/9/06. ==Child abuse prevention == Kelley has specialized in the field of [[child abuse]], since 1979 and has appeared as a featured expert on child abuse on national programs including the [[Today (NBC program)|Today Show]], [[NBC Evening News]] and [[CBS Morning News]]. ===Child abuse unethical interviews=== As a pediatric nurse in the 1980s, Kelley interviewed many of the children involved in the [[Fells Acres Day Care Center]] sexual abuse case in [[Malden, Massachusetts]].{{cite news |first=D |last=Rabinowitz |authorlink=Dorothy Rabinowitz |coauthors= |title=A Darkness in Massachusetts--II |url=http://opinionjournal.com/extra/?id=95000780 |publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date= 1995-03-14 |accessdate=2009-02-21 }} Kelley’s interview techniques in that case later came under criticism and were called “improper” and “biased” by a Massachusetts appellate judge[http://users.rcn.com/kyp/borenstn.html Transcript of June 12, 1998] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080904224801/http://users.rcn.com/kyp/borenstn.html |date=September 4, 2008 }} Judge Isaac Borenstein after video tapes of her questioning of the children were played in court during the appeal of one of the defendants.{{cite news | last = Hayward | first = E | title = Prof: Therapist Swayed Kids against Amiraults | publisher = [[Boston Herald]] | date = 1998-02-18 }}{{cite news |first= C |last= Goldberg |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Youths' "Tainted" Testimony Is Barred in Day Care Retrial. One police officer, John Rivers, said at a seminar that interviewing the children was "like getting blood from a stone." This comment was made in reference to her almost forcing children to admit to false experiences. |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C04E1DC163DF930A25755C0A96E958260 |publisher = [[The New York Times]] |date= 1998-06-13 | accessdate = 2009-02-21 }} ==Awards and honors== *[[International Cultic Studies Association|ICSA's]] John G. Clark Award for Distinguished Scholarship in Cultic Studies[[Recovery from Cults (book)]], [[Michael Langone]], [[Ph.D.]], ed., p. xii
''Susan J. Kelley, [[Ph.D.]], [[Registered Nurse|R.N.]]'' is Associate Professor of Nursing at Boston College. Dr. Kelley is editor of ''Pediatric Emergency Nursing'' (Appleton & Lange), for which she received the American Journal of Nursing Book of the Year Award. Dr. Kelley also received the John G. Clark Award for Distinguished Scholarship in Cultic Studies for her research comparing ritually abused and sexually abused children in day care. *[[American Journal of Nursing]] Book of the Year Award *[[March of Dimes]] National Nurse of the Year Award *[[American Nurses' Association]] Nurse of the Year Award{{citation needed|date=November 2014}} *Excellence in Research Award, Society of Pediatric Nursing{{citation needed|date=November 2014}} *Outstanding Service Award, [[American Professional Society on the Abuse of Children]] *Fellow of the [[American Academy of Nursing]]{{citation needed|date=November 2014}} ==Professional associations== *Former President, Georgia Professional Society on the Abuse of Children{{citation needed|date=November 2014}} *Member, Advisory Board, American Professional Society on the Abuse of Children (APSAC){{citation needed|date=November 2014}} *Member, [[Board of Directors]], Georgia Council on Child Abuse{{citation needed|date=November 2014}} *Member, Board of Directors, Pediatric Services of America, Inc. (Nasdaq: PSAI)"Pediatric Services of America, Inc. Announces Appointment..", [[Business Wire]], July 29, 2003. *Member, editorial boards: **''Child Maltreatment'' **''Journal of Child Sexual Abuse'' **''Trauma, Violence and Abuse: A Review Journal'' ==Publications== ===Books=== *''[[Pediatric Emergency Nursing]]'', published by [[Appleton & Lange]], April 2, 1995, {{ISBN|0-8385-7705-9}}, {{ISBN|978-0-8385-7705-9}} *''[[Recovery from Cults (book)|Recovery from Cults: Help for Victims of Psychological and Spiritual Abuse]]'', Contributor, 1995 ===Articles=== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070129081308/http://www.icsahome.com/infoserv_articles/kelley_susan_ritualisticabuseofchildren_abs.htm Ritualistic Abuse of Children: Dynamics and Impact], ''[[Cultic Studies Review|Cultic Studies Journal]]'', Vol. 5, No. 2 *"Grandmothers raising grandchildren: Are they at increased risk of health problems?", ''Health & Social Work '', Volume: 26 Issue: 2 Page: 105-114, May 31, 2001 *"A multimodal intervention for grandparents raising grandchildren: Results of an exploratory study", ''Child Welfare '', Volume: 80 Issue: 1 Page: 27-50, February 28, 2001 ==See also== {{Portal|Nursing}} *[[List of psychologists]] *[[Day care sex abuse hysteria]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kelley, Susan J.}} [[Category:American psychologists]] [[Category:American women psychologists]] [[Category:American nurses]] [[Category:American women nurses]] [[Category:Nursing school deans]] [[Category:Nursing educators]] [[Category:Nursing researchers]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Academy of Nursing]] [[Category:Georgia State University faculty]] [[Category:George Mason University faculty]] [[Category:Boston College faculty]] [[Category:Boston University alumni]] [[Category:Boston College alumni]] [[Category:Living people]]

revision.text:
{{distinguish|text=its first campus, [[The College of William & Mary]]}}
{{Infobox University |name = The Colleges of William & Mary |image_name = |image_size = |established = 1960 |closed = 1962 |type = [[Public university|Public]] |chancellor = [[Alvin Duke Chandler]] |city = [[Virginia]] <!-- In city field to avoid errant comma --> |country = [[United States]] |campus = Multi-Campus University }} '''The Colleges of William & Mary''' was the name of a short-lived educational system in [[Virginia]]. It included The [[College of William & Mary]], the [[Richmond Professional Institute]], the [[Old Dominion University|Norfolk Division of the College of William & Mary]], [[Christopher Newport University|Christopher Newport College]], and [[Richard Bland College]].<ref name="CoWMAH">{{cite book|last=Godson|title=The College of William and Mary: A History|year=1993|publisher=King and Queen Press|isbn=0-9615670-4-X|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
==Creation== In 1960, The College of William & Mary ("The College") had two branch campuses, the [[Richmond Professional Institute]] (RPI), which it had operated since 1925, and the [[Old Dominion University|Norfolk Division of the College of William & Mary]], which it had operated since 1930.
The [[General Assembly of Virginia]] passed H.B. 466 creating The Colleges of William & Mary ("The Colleges") on March 3, 1960, and it took effect immediately.<ref name=acts>{{cite book|title=Index of Acts of the General Assembly of the Commonwealth of Virginia|year=1972|publisher=Commonwealth of Virginia|location=Richmond}}</ref> The president of The College, [[Alvin Duke Chandler]], was chosen to be the administrative chancellor of the new system, with [[Davis Young Paschall]] replacing him as president.
==Operation== As chancellor, however, Chandler attempted to manage the day-to-day operations of all five branches of The Colleges and, by doing so, began to alienate the presidents who served under him. The presidents of The College, RPI, and the Norfolk Division were originally to have more autonomy under the new system than they had had in the past.<ref>{{cite news|last=Carter|first=Luther|title=With Chandler Appointment Area College System Begun|newspaper=The Virginian-Pilot|date=29 May 1960}}</ref> However, Chandler did not allow that to happen. For example, Chandler required Lewis Webb, president of the Norfolk Division, to seek his approval in matters of hiring faculty and staff, granting leaves of absence, reviewing scholarly publications, and budget requests.<ref name="CoWMAH"/> Chandler also referred to the five college system as his "empire,"<ref>{{cite news|last=Brown|first=Alexander C.|title=The Chancellors of William and Mary|newspaper=Daily Press|date=30 May 1965}}</ref> reflecting his idea of his role at the top. He also maintained an office on the campus of The College, saying that he could not see how "the college chancellor possibly could conduct business away from the campus."<ref>{{cite news|title=Office Slated for Chandler in Ewell Hall|newspaper=Daily Press|date=7 July 1960}}</ref>
In addition, the Norfolk Division was granted accreditation in its own right from the [[Southern Association of Colleges and Schools]] as a four-year college in December 1961 and was renamed the [[Old Dominion University|Norfolk College of the Colleges of William & Mary]].<ref name="CoWMAH"/> RPI had been accredited in its own right since 1953.<ref>{{cite web|title=Institution Details|url=http://sacscoc.org/details.asp?instid=78480|publisher=Southern Association of Colleges and Schools|accessdate=21 July 2011}}</ref> As four-year schools with their own accreditation, the presidents of each began to resent the level of influence Chandler had in their day-to-day affairs and began to look for ways to change it.<ref name="CoWMAH"/>
==Dissolution== The [[Virginia General Assembly|General Assembly]] decided to split the system into three parts, with The College, RPI, and the Norfolk College each having their own [[Board of Visitors|Boards of Visitors]] and with [[Richard Bland College]] and [[Christopher Newport University|Christopher Newport College]] remaining under the control of the Board of Visitors of The College of William & Mary.<ref>{{cite news|last=McNair|first=Sandy|title=W&M Reorganization Bill is Set for Senate Passage; Governor's Approval Seen|hdl=10288/3670|newspaper=The Flat Hat|date=9 February 1962}}</ref> The bill for the dissolution of the system was introduced by [[Virginia House of Delegates|Delegate]] Russell Carneal of Williamburg at the urging of some of the members of the Board of Visitors.<ref name="CoWMAH"/> However, other members of the Board of Visitors were opposed; there had been a vote of the Board against the dissolution of the system in December 1961.<ref name="Mol">{{cite news|last=Molineux|first=Will|title=Chandler Appointed College Coordinator|newspaper=Daily Press|date=20 May 1962}}</ref> The dissolution became official with the passage of H.B. 156, signed into law by Governor [[Albertis Harrison]] on February 16, 1962.<ref name="acts"/> It specified that the system would be abolished as of July 1, 1962.
Upon its independence, the Norfolk College became Old Dominion College, now known as [[Old Dominion University]]. RPI remained an independent state school until 1968, when it merged with the [[Medical College of Virginia]] to form [[Virginia Commonwealth University]]. Christopher Newport College remained an extension of The College until becoming independent in 1977, and became [[Christopher Newport University]] in 1992. Richard Bland College remains a junior college affiliated with The College.
After the dissolution of the system, Alvin Duke Chandler served as the coordinator for Christopher Newport College and Richard Bland College;<ref name="Mol"/> however, he resigned this position after only four months. He then became [[Chancellor of the College of William & Mary|chancellor]] of the College of William & Mary, an honorary position that dates back to the founding of the College.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wm.edu/about/administration/chancellor/postcolonial/index.php|title=Post-Colonial Era Chancellors|publisher=The College of William & Mary|accessdate=21 July 2011}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{College of William & Mary}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Colleges of William and Mary, The}} [[Category:College of William & Mary]] [[Category:Christopher Newport University]] [[Category:Old Dominion University]] [[Category:Virginia Commonwealth University]] [[Category:Public universities]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Virginia]] [[Category:Public university systems in the United States]]

revision.text: {{Infobox information appliance | name = Topo | title = | aka = | logo = | image = | caption = | developer = William H.T. La[http://www.smallrobot.com/topoii.pdf TOPO II OWNER'S MANUAL], ''Acknowledgements: ...The original product concept and the name "TOPO" were developed by William H.T. La''[http://www.theoldrobots.com/Fetal.html Fetal I Robot], , ''Fetal I Robot - Fetal-I an omnidirectional base designed by William H T La. Fetal I is a TOPO at heart with a new wood exteriour and new wheels.'', The Old Robots Web Site | manufacturer = [[Androbot]] Inc.[http://www.theoldrobots.com/bob3.html Androbot Topo and BOB Robots] The Old Robot's Web Site[http://www.robotgallery.com/robotgallery/androbot/index.html Meet the Androbots (TOPO I, TOPO II, TOPO III, BOB, BOB/XA, FRED, Androman, and the Axlon robots)], www.robotgallery.com[http://www.inc.com/magazine/19830301/6181.html Will The Robot Be Father To The Industry?], Published on: Mar 1, 1983, Inc.com[http://www.inc.com/magazine/19841001/136.html When The Magic Goes], Published on: Oct 1, 1984, Inc.com[https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/1983/07/06/merrill-lynch-bullish-on-robot/49f442a8-a766-401a-9983-03983d4e9ff0/ Merrill Lynch Bullish on Robot], By Michael Schrage, 1983-07-06, The Washington Post | family = | type = [[robot]] | generation = | releasedate = {{Start date|1983}}[http://www.atarimagazines.com/compute/issue42/043_1_REVIEWS.php Review: Androbot's Topo], By Michael A. Tyborski, COMPUTE! ISSUE 42 / NOVEMBER 1983 / PAGE 156[https://books.google.com.au/books?id=wS8EAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA103&ots=ofmw04sDgb&dq=topo%20robot%201983&pg=PA103#v=onepage&q=topo%20robot%201983&f=false Robot-maker Androbot pulls stock offering], By Kathy Chin, InfoWorld, 14 Nov 1983 | lifespan = | price = {{USD|495|1983}} | discontinued = TOPO I - {{End date|1984|04}}[https://books.google.com.au/books?id=sy4EAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA13&ots=0DGA51B_SZ&dq=topo%20robot%201983&pg=PA12#v=onepage&q=topo%20robot%201983&f=false TOPO Gets new lease on life: Robot now operates with Commodore, IBM computers], By Peggy Watt, InfoWorld 14 May 1984, Page 12-13 | unitssold = 120 | unitsshipped = 650 | media = | os = | power = | soc = | cpu = | memory = | storage = | memory card = | display = | graphics = | sound = | input = | controllers = | camera = | touchpad = | connectivity = | platform = | service = | dimensions = | weight = | topgame = | compatibility= | predecessor = | successor = TOPO II, TOPO III, BOB, BOB/XA, FRED, ANDROMAN[https://books.google.com.au/books?id=Gj2ebZ9EBTAC&lpg=PA63&ots=Li4SQtKQOg&dq=%22TOPO%20II%22%20%20%09Androbot&pg=PA63#v=onepage&q=%22TOPO%20II%22%20%20%09Androbot&f=false A Small World: Smart Houses and the Dream of the Perfect Day], By Davin Heckman, Page 53, ''...Throughout the early 1980s, Androbot Incorporated released a number of personal robots, including, TOPO I, TOPO II, TOPO III, BOB, BOB/XA, FRED, ANDROMAN...''[https://books.google.com.au/books?id=7jeH7OGPwUUC&lpg=PA142&ots=D3U-eBnSF_&dq=%22BOB%2FXA%22%20robot&pg=PA142#v=onepage&q=%22BOB/XA%22%20robot&f=false BOB], PC Mag 21 Aug 1984, Page 142-143[https://books.google.com.au/books?id=iC4EAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA16&ots=2GwLOnjZUD&dq=%22BOB%2FXA%22%20robot&pg=PA16#v=onepage&q=%22BOB/XA%22%20robot&f=false People:Nolan Bushnell], By Denise Caruso, InfoWorld, 30 Apr 1984, Page 16, ''Nolan Bushnell desires a robot with a more shapely configuration. ... BOB/XA (Brains on Board/Expandable Androbot), the latest personal robot from Androbot'' | related = | website = }} '''Topo''' is a [[robot]] designed in the 1980s by [[Androbot]] Inc., for the consumer and education markets. It was programmable via [[Apple II]] and there was also a user made program for the [[Windows 9x]] operating systems{{cn|date=May 2016}}. The programming language allows the robot to perform a set of geometric movements, to move about a room and perform tasks. It was like a servant robot, although it did not truly meet the requirements of a robot, as it had no sensors to use to receive input and then make decisions accordingly.[http://www.smallrobot.com/topoii.html Topo: The world's first personal robots, from Androbot.][http://www.gettyimages.ca/detail/news-photo/tom-frisina-president-of-androbot-inc-holds-a-topos-model-news-photo/635239835 Picture], ''Tom Frisina, president of Androbot Inc., holds a Topos model personal robot. He sits in front of a background showing the surface of the moon, with the earth hanging in the sky above. The robot is designed to perform everyday tasks around the house.'', March 05, 1983, Credit: Corbis, Getty Images[http://www.gettyimages.com.au/detail/news-photo/tom-frisina-president-of-androbot-inc-holds-a-sensor-for-a-news-photo/635239729 Picture], ''Tom Frisina, president of Androbot Inc., holds a sensor for a Topos model personal robot. The robot is designed to perform everyday tasks around the house.'', March 05, 1983, Credit: Corbis, Getty Images The robots were sold commercially starting in early 1983, and were intended to be inexpensive, lacking a complicated [[Robotic end effector|manipulating device]]. Units were beige molded plastic with two drive wheels as "feet" and stood about 36 inches tall. Arms on Topo 1 and 2 would fold out, but Topo 3 lacked arms altogether. Operation was based on one of two [[programming language]]s, either [[Apple BASIC]], a modified version of the [[Logo (programming language)|Logo]] language, or a version of [[Forth (programming language)|Forth]]. Communication was via a radio or infrared transmitter attached to a personal computer. Topo 2 and 3 used an infrared transmitter, and could be controlled by a four way pad on the top of their head that also served as the infrared receiver. In its final versions, Topo abilities included a text-to-speech processor, so that users could program their robots to wander around the house and "speak" to humans. However, a fourth model was made but it never went into production (a Topo IV sheet was mailed during the final days of Androbot). It was more like the [[Brains On Board|B.O.B.]] (Brains On Board, an unreleased robot that was produced after the Topo series) robot than a Topo. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Portal|Robotics}} * [https://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/androbot/info Androbot owners group], Yahoo Groups *{{youtube|e79dzJcSXfM|Topo Androbot}} * [http://www.robotgallery.com/robotgallery/androbot/index.html Here Come the Androbots] *[http://www.megadroid.com/Companies/androbot.htm The History of Androbot], Pieced together by Rick Rowland *[http://www.atarimuseum.com/otherprojects/nonatari/androbot/andro-atari.html The Atari Androbot Projects] ** [http://www.atarimuseum.com/archives/pdf/misc/topo1and2_schematics.PDF Original Androbot Pre-release Schematics of the TOPO I & TOPO II Robots.] *[http://commodorez.tumblr.com/post/118563604519/rockasoo-androbot-and-axlon-androbot-and-axlon Androbot and Axlon], May 9th, 2015, Commodore Z's Mindhouse [[Category:Educational robots]] [[Category:1983 robots]] [[Category:Rolling robots]] [[Category:Robots of the United States]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Use British English|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox person |image = Tuppy Owens 1998 1.jpg |caption = Tuppy Owens in 1998 |birth_name = Rosalind Mary Owens |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1944|11|12|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Cambridge]], [[England]] |occupation = Writer, therapist, campaigner |years_active = 1970–present }}
'''Rosalind Mary Owens''' (born 12 November 1944), known as '''Tuppy Owens''', is an English sex therapist, consultant, campaigner, writer and former adult model.<ref name=sexis1118103/><ref name=theskinny20080617/><ref name="highbeam.com">{{cite journal|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-18669012.html|title=BBC under fire for porn star's Viagra love-making|date=19 August 1998|publisher=}}</ref>
==Education== Tuppy Owens was born in [[Cambridge]]. She gained a degree in [[zoology]] from [[Exeter University]], and then worked in [[ecology]] in [[Africa]] and [[Trinidad]].<ref name=sexis1118103/> She settled in [[London]], and worked as a scientific administrator at the [[Natural Environment Research Council]].<ref name=observer19720924/> Then, in the late 1960s, she established a sex education book publishing company, for which she wrote and published ''The Sex Maniac’s Diary''<ref name=paulharris/> successfully between 1972 and 1995, and which she operated as a thriving business from her [[Mayfair]] flat<ref name=observer19720924/> — for example, the 1975 ''Sex Maniac's Diary'' was launched in August 1974 with a reception at the Bristol Hotel in London which was reported on the following day in the [[Financial Times]].<ref name=ft19740822/>
==Work==
From 1974, Tuppy Owens also began lecturing on the subject of sex.<ref name=es19740409/> In 1975, she appeared in the Dutch pornographic film ''Sensations''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pre-cert.co.uk/display.php?vId=UK13009|title=Sensations (1975) on Video Blue|website=Pre-Certification Video}}</ref> From 1984, the ''Sex Maniac's Diary'' was published as ''The Safer Sex Maniac's Diary'' and provided the first visual instructions to the public on how to put a [[condom]] on securely; it also reviewed condoms and offered [[Safe sex|safer sex]] advice, all at the beginning of the outbreak of [[HIV]].<ref name=thediary/>
In 1979, Owens started the Outsiders Club for socially and physically disabled people to find partners. She was helped by Nigel Verbeek, who had recently lost his sight. Both worked voluntarily, which Tuppy continues to do today. Outsiders is a warm and friendly club providing peer support to members, a beautiful online Clubhouse, and lovely monthly lunches around the country.
In order to ensure that she answered the members' questions with accuracy, Owens trained as a [[sex therapist]] at [[St George's Hospital Medical School]] in London, where she gained a diploma in Human Sexuality in 1986.<ref name=theskinny20080617/> She was also subsequently awarded an Honorary Doctorate from the Institute of Advanced Study of Human Sexuality in [[San Francisco]].<ref name=theskinny20080617/> In 2009, Owens was named one of the Family Planning Association‘s 80 most influential achievers in the field of family planning.
For disabled men and women who want to learn what pleasures their bodies are capable of enjoying, and how to please a partner, Owens set up the TLC Trust website, where they can find responsible, safe sexual services.
In 1981, Owens appeared in the English pornographic film ''Lady Victoria's Training'', which was produced by Mike Freeman/Videx and featured Simon Linsday Honey, who went on to work as a porn producer and actor in 1990's under the pseudonym [[Ben Dover]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pre-cert.co.uk/display.php?vId=UK09550|title=Lady Victoria's Training (1981) on Videx|website=Pre-Certification Video}}</ref><ref name="highbeam.com"/>
In the 1990s, after more than 30 years living in London, Tuppy Owens moved away from that city. Since then, she has lived in a croft in the north of Scotland.<ref name=highladnews20060608/>
In 2005, Tuppy Owens founded the Sexual Health and Disability Alliance (SHADA)<ref name=sexis1118103/> to bring together health professionals interested in sex and disability. In November 2009, a conference with the title "Disability: Sex, Relationships and Pleasure" was held by SHADA with the [[Royal Society of Medicine]].<ref name=rsm20091113/> Tuppy produced the Sexual Respect Tool Kit, and started the sexual advocacy service, ASAP. Tuppy also answers the Sex and Disability Helpline. Her book "Supporting Disabled People with their Sexual Lives" was published by [[Jessica Kingsley Publishers|Jessica Kingsley]] on 19 November 2014.
Tuppy Owens remains active in running Outsiders.<ref name=realist136/> At the same time, she also advises the promoter of the Sexual Freedom Ball to fund Outsiders, and the organisers of the fundraiser, The [[Erotic Awards]],<ref name=thetimes1085069/> now called The Sexual Services and Entertainment Awards.
Owens is now the chair of the Sexual Freedom Coalition.<ref name=marieclaire200903/> Back in the 90s Owens worked campaigning with Prostitution Pride, parades through London, which were funded by Arcadia events in North London.
Owens has been working with the Bath Institute of Medical Engineering in the hope that they will be able to create sex toys that can be used by disabled people who, without them, cannot masturbate.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Owens|first1=Tuppy|title=Supporting disabled residents to enjoy masturbation and sexual services|url=http://shadainternational.com/all-impairments/pioneers/|website=Shada International|accessdate=11 April 2018}}</ref>
Owens will be the editor of a forthcoming website, The School of Sex for Disabled People, which is being created by sexually experienced disabled people and those who provide them with sexual services. She is currently writing her autobiography.
==Award== Owens has won the 2015 Lifetime Achievement Award from the European Lifestyles Awards. She is also a Winner of the Innovation Award of Sexual Health and Human Rights UNESCO 2015. She was a finalist (Lifetime Achievement) in the Directory of Social Change Awards 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=Press Release: 2015 Social Change Awards Ceremony|url=https://www.dsc.org.uk/content/2015-social-change-awards-ceremony/|website=Directory of Social Change|accessdate=11 April 2018|language=en}}</ref>
==Publications== * Photographs of caterpillars in Trinidad Scientific American: August 1967 * ''Sexual Harmony''. London: Highbury Press, 1969 * ''Love in the Open Air''. London: Cand Haven Ltd., 1970 * ''The Sex Maniac's Diary''. London: Cand Haven Ltd., 1972-1995 (from 1987 called ''The Safer Sex Maniac's Diary'') * Column in ''Club International''. London: Paul Raymond Publications, 1975–6 * ''Take Me I'm Yours''. Edinburgh: Paul Harris Publishing, 1978 * ''Mothercare Diary''. London: Readers Digest, 1980 * ''Practical Suggestions''. London: Outsiders Trust, from 1980 to present * ''Emotions in Focus'' — catalogue of the Exhibition of the same name which opened at The Round House in 1983 (International Year of Disabled People). London: the Outsiders Trust, 1983 * ''INSIDE''. London: the Outsiders Trust, 1984–1998 and 2002–present * ''The Sex Maniac's Bible''. London: Cand Haven Ltd., 1989 * ''The Sex Maniac's Address Book''. London: Cand Haven Ltd., 1989 * ''Little Book of Delights'' (annually). London: the Leydig Trust, 1989–present * ''The Organ monthly''. London: Cand Haven Ltd., 1990–1993 * ''The Making of Sensations''. New York: Rhinoceros, 1993 * Introduction to ''Half Dressed, She Obeyed''. Stockport: Divine Press, 1993 * ''The Politically Correct Guide to Getting Laid''. London: Cand Haven Ltd., 1995 * ''The Sexual Skills and Needs of Disabled Men — A Female Perspective Sexuality & Disability Journal''. New York: Kluwer Academic/Human Sciences Press, 1996 * ''Planet Sex — The Handbook''. London: Cand Haven Ltd, 1996 * ''Disabled People Make the Best Clients'' presented at the ICOP Conference, Los Angeles 1997 and then globally * A column in ''Desire'' 2000–2008 * Contributions to ''The Sex Book''. London: Cassells, 2002 * Foreword to ''Baby Oil and Ice''. London: The Do-Not Press, 2002 * Columns in ''Forum'' and ''Erotic Review'', 2005–2009 * Content for the Sex and Disability section of the Lovers' Guide website 2007 * ''Philip's Aspidistra: the Owens' Bequest'' in ''About Larkin'', Journal of the Philip Larkin Society No 24, October 2007 * ''Sex and Disability'', an article on TheSite.org, Youthnet, 2009 * Chapters in ''A Guide to Sexual Dysfunction in Men''. Leicestershire: Troubador Publishing Ltd., 2010 * ''Ten Things to Know About Sex and Disability''. London: Royal College of Art and Imperial College, 2010 * Chapter entitled ''Disability and Sex Work '' in book Queer Sex Work, Taylor and Francis Books 2014 * ''Supporting Disabled People with their Sexual Lives, — a clear guide for health and social care professionals '' Jessica Kingsley 2014
==References==

September 1972: article by Pendennis ''Tuppyware''</ref> <ref name=es19740409>''[[The Evening Standard]]'', Tuesday 9 April 1974, page 5: article by David Bentley ''Tuppy finds a way with the little red love book''</ref> <ref name=ft19740822>''[[The Financial Times]]'', Thursday 22 August 1974</ref> <ref name=realist136>''[[The Realist]]'', Number 136: article by David Steinberg ''The Hookers Convention''</ref> <ref name=thetimes1085069>{{cite news|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/article1085069.ece|work=[[The Times]]|date=30 August 2006|author=[[Grayson Perry]]|title=I'm all for good, clean dirty fun, me|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090501061755/http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/article1085069.ece|archivedate=1 May 2009|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> <ref name=highladnews20060608>{{cite web|url=http://www.highland-news.co.uk/Home/Features/Northern-sexposure-56.htm|date=8 June 2008|title=Northern sexposure''}}Highland News: article about Dr Owens</ref> <ref name=theskinny20080617>{{cite web|url=http://www.theskinny.co.uk/article/42948-tuppy-owens-interview-with-a-love-doctor|work=[[The Skinny (magazine)|The Skinny]]|date=17 June 2008|title=Tuppy Owens: Interview with a Love Doctor''|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090211074100/http://www.theskinny.co.uk/article/42948-tuppy-owens-interview-with-a-love-doctor|archivedate=11 February 2009|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> <ref name=paulharris>Excerpt at allmediaScotland, 2 October 2008 from memoirs of Scottish war correspondent Paul Harris [http://www.allmediascotland.com/press_news/14481/More-Thrills-than-Skills---A-Half-life-in-Journalism,-Part-68 ''More Thrills than Skills — A Half-life in Journalism, Part 68'']</ref> <ref name=marieclaire200903>''[[Marie Claire]]'' March 2009: article ''Meet the Sex Professionals''</ref> <ref name=rsm20091113>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsm.ac.uk/academ/sej101.php|title=Disability: Sex, relationships and pleasure|publisher=[[Royal Society of Medicine]]|date=13 November 2009|archivedate=29 October 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091029113922/http://www.rsm.ac.uk/academ/sej101.php|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> <ref name=sexis1118103>Cole Riley, ''[[SexIs]]'' magazine & website, 18 November 2010: article [http://www.edenfantasys.com/sexis/sexual-health/tuppy-owens-sex-and-disability-1118103/ ''Dr. Tuppy Owens: The Sensual Patron Saint of the Disabled'']</ref> }}

page.title: Universidad Católica de Santo Tomás de Villanueva

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Roman Catholic universities and colleges in Cuba to [[:Category:Catholic universities and colleges in Cuba]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2017 September 10]].
revision.text:
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:St thomas villanova pin.jpg|thumb|right|210px|Pin from Universidad Católica de Santo Tomás de Villanueva {{puic|Image:St thomas villanova pin.jpg|log=2008 July 20}}]] --> '''Universidad Católica de Santo Tomás de Villanueva''' (''St. Thomas of Villanova Catholic University'') was a private [[Roman Catholic]] [[university]] founded on August 15, 1946, in [[Havana]], [[Cuba]]. It was founded by American [[Augustinians]] with assistance from European Augustinians and named after [[Thomas of Villanova|Saint Thomas of Villanova]]. In 1957, it was declared a [[pontifical university]]. In 1961, the Augustinians were expelled from Cuba and the university was confiscated by the Cuban government.
Former members of its faculty later helped found [[Biscayne College]], now [[St. Thomas University (Florida)|St. Thomas University]], in [[Miami Gardens]], [[Florida]].
In 2007, a group of Catholic university students presented a petition to the Cuban government asking for the Universidad Católica de Santo Tomás de Villanueva to reopen.<ref>Associated Press, "Activists Seek Independent Cuba Colleges" by Will Weissert, November 27, 2007</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} Boza Masvidal - tribunal prosecuter, intellectual revolutionary
==See also== *[[St. Thomas University (Florida)]]

'''Whiteplains British School''' ('''WBS''') is a (day and boarding) international co-education located in Jabi, [[Abuja|Abuja Municipal Area Council (AMAC)]], [[Federal Capital Territory, Nigeria|FCT-Abuja]], [[Nigeria]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailytrust.com.ng/news/education/abuja-private-schools-charge-high-fees/128826.html|title=Abuja private schools charge high fees|authors=Misbahu, Bashir & Chidimma C. Okeke|date=3 January 2016|publisher=Daily Trust Newspaper|website=www.dailytrust.com.ng}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nigerianmonitor.com/10-most-expensive-schools-in-nigeria-million-naira-fees/|title=10 Most Expensive Secondary Schools in Nigeria|first =Odu|last=Opeyemi|date=12 April 2016|publisher=Nigerian Mirror|website=www.nigerianmonitor.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://guardian.ng/features/education/private-schools-to-raise-fees-as-fuel-price-goes-up/|title=Private schools to raise fees as fuel price goes up|authors=Adekunle, Ruth & Kanayo Oguegbu|date=19 May 2016|publisher=The Guuardian Newspaper|website=www.guardian.ng}}</ref>
==History and geography== WBS was founded by a group of private individuals. It was incorporated as Whiteplains British School Ltd under the Companies and Allied Matters Act 1990 on 2 May 2007. ''People Monthly'' magazine reports that Whiteplains British School 'was born from a desire by few Nigerians in Diaspora to offer an excellent school whose program is designed to provide Nigerians and other nationals living in [[Nigeria]] with a certificate that is recognised throughout the world.'<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Whiteplains British School...A Place for Growing Minds|author=Egwu, Ngozi|publisher=''People Monthly'' Magazine|location=Abuja|year=March 2008 |issue=11|page=56}}</ref>
WBS has two campuses. While the first campus is a [[primary school]] and administrative block located at Plot 528 [[Cadastral]] Zone B4, Jabi, the second campus, which harbours the [[secondary school]] and the advanced studies department, is seated on a [[land mass]] of 4.5 hectares in Daki Bui, Jabi, [[Abuja]]. Whiteplains British School has a close affiliation with a number of partner foreign universities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://peoplemonthlyonline.ng/top-10-secondary-schools-abuja/|title=The Top 10 Secondary Schools in Abuja|author=Oyinlola, Adeyemi|date=11 February 2016|publisher=People Monthly Online|website=www.peoplemonthlyonline.ng/}}</ref>
== Curricula == Whiteplains prepares students for [[pre-school]], [[primary school]], [[secondary school]], Advanced and [[University]] Foundation Studies. It also offers [[Cambridge]]-accredited one–year A’ Level, Cambridge Traditional two–years’ A’ Level and University Degree Foundation courses. The school is listed as one of Nigeria’s centres of [[Edexcel]] Academic Qualification.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://qualifications.pearson.com/content/dam/pdf/Support/find-an-international-centre/List_of_centres_offering_EDEXCEL_qualifications_07112016.xls|title=List of Centres Offering EDEXCEL Qualification|accessdate=4 July 2017|website=www.qualifications.pearson.com}}</ref> As a provisional member of the [[Council of British International Schools]] and the [[New England Association of Schools and Colleges]], WBS runs both Nigerian and British curricula. Whiteplains uses the [[student-centred]] teaching method. Its academic calendar operates on three terms beginning in early September and ending in mid-July.
== General facilities ==
The school's facilities include separate air-conditioned hostels for male and female boarding students, sports facilities, libraries, [[Information and communications technology|ICT]] facilities, an auditorium, swimming pool,[[language]] and [[science]] laboratories, etc.
== Extra-curricular activities ==
As part of its curricular activities, WBS offers opportunities in [[music]], [[dance]] and [[theatre]], art production and exhibition and [[science fair]], [[taekwondo]]/[[karate]], swimming, [[Press Club]], Debating Club, Environmental Club, and Entrepreneurial Club, Art Club, Dance Club and Music Club. Annually, it also observes the [[International Women’s Day]], [[Nigeria]]’s [[Children’s Day]] (May 27), and [[Independence Day]] (1 October). The school celebrated its 7th Graduation Ceremony in 2015.
On 11 March 2017, four students of WBS displayed their discovered Surveillance Drone, Online Store, Online Crossword Puzzle, and a social networking site.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201604130086.html|title=Nigeria: Four Teenagers Rattle Global Market With New Innovations|first=Solomon|last=Nda-Isaiah|date=13 April 2016|publisher=|via=AllAfrica powered by ''Leadership'' Newspaper}}</ref> The school was enlisted as one of the three venues in the 2017 [[Toyota]] [[Nigeria]] Dream Car Art Contest.
== Academics == For admission WBS charges a non-refundable application fee, non-refundable Capital Development Levy, [[tuition]] and boarding fees, school uniform fee, medical screening with medical insurance fee, and has an entrance examination.
The school was selected as the Best [[Secondary School]] of the Year 2012 by the Institute of Government Research and Development.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.instituteforgovernmentresearch.org/bennwabueze2.html|title=Institute for Government Research - Annual Events|website=www.instituteforgovernmentresearch.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/document/354362948/Speech-Delivered-by-Dr-Francis-Chukwuma-Nwufoh|title=Speech Delivered by Dr Francis Chukwumah Nwufoh|first=Echezonachukwu|last=Ononukwe|accessdate=21 July 2017|publisher=SCRIBD|website=www.scribd.com}}</ref>

{{Multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=June 2009|att=October 2017}} {{sources|date=June 2009}} }}
{{Infobox |title = WiRED International |label2 = Founder | data2 = Gary Selnow, Ph.D. |label3 = Founded | data3 = 1997 |label4 = Type | data4 = 501(3)(c) non-profit organization |label5 = Location | data5 = Montara, CA |label6 = Services | data6 = Providing health information to underserved communities of the world |label7 = Fields | data7 = Health Information, Global Health |label8 = Key people | data8 = Dr. Gary Selnow (Director) & [http://www.wiredinternational.org/board.html WiRED Governing Board] |label9 = Slogan | data9 = To address health knowledge inequality |label10 = Mission Statement | data10 = WIRED International is a non-profit, volunteer-driven organization that provides vital medical information and education to underserved communities in regions challenged by war, poverty and dislocation. WiRED’s Community Health Information Libraries offer medical and health information enabling physicians and nurses, community health workers and individuals in developing areas of the world to address the prevention and treatment of infectious and non-communicable disease. All WiRED’s resources—online and on portable media—are cost-free to users. |label11 = Websites | data11 = http://www.wiredinternational.org/ http://www.wiredhealthresources.net/ }}
'''WiRED International''' is a 501(c)(3)non-profit, volunteer-driven organization that has been delivering medical and health information to war-affected and underserved regions since 1997. WiRED International’s goal is to address the severe global inequality of health knowledge.
WiRED International provides health information to underdeveloped areas by delivering programs, equipment and coordinated health education. Over the years, the organization has opened facilities in 15 countries, while NGOs, medical schools and hospitals in many additional countries have adopted its programs for community health education. The organization serves remote regions and, when appropriate, supplies laptops, projectors, solar equipment and complete health education libraries.
All WiRED International’s resources online and on portable media are cost-free to users.
WiRED International’s educational programs are technology-based. Starting in the 1990s, the organization stored programs on floppy disks and CD-ROMS and today relies on the Internet and flash drives. With this technology, people can put hundreds of training programs in their pockets, to take beyond the grid. These programs can be run on portable laptops and projectors for group presentations.
In 2009, the University of California, Berkeley, School of Public Health awarded WiRED International its Organizational Public Health Hero Award. WiRED earned the award “for its achievements in using information technology to provide up-to-date health education and medical information in developing, post-conflict, and isolated regions of the world.”
== History == San Francisco State University professor, Gary Selnow, Ph.D., founded WiRED International in 1997 while on a Fulbright Fellowship as a visiting professor at the [[University of Zagreb]] in Croatia right after the [[Yugoslav War]]. Selnow said, “UNICEF had donated computers to a high school in [[Vukovar]], Croatia, but they were sitting in boxes. We connected them to the Internet.”
Within two years, after formally registering as an NGO, WiRED International had established technology-based programs in six of the former Yugoslav countries. The U.S. Department of State engaged WiRED International’s services in Bosnia and then in Kosovo, where the organization’s volunteers set up community-access Internet centers to help people find family members who fled during the conflict with Serbia. Dr. Selnow noted that physicians made up “the largest group visiting the centers in Kosovo.”
As a small and flexible organization, WiRED International can respond quickly to community needs. While most of its work deals with health education, occasionally the organization comes across circumstances that merit special attention. One example took place in Kosovo in 1999, where a number of children had been unable to receive adequate treatment for life-threatening illnesses because of a war-damaged health care system.
Selnow was traveling by van from [[Pristina|Prishtina]] (Priština), Kosovo, to [[Skopje]], Macedonia, which, at the time, had the nearest operational airport. In the van was a five-year-old boy and a nurse. The nurse explained that [[Medecins Sans Frontieres]] was funding the boy’s travel to France for heart surgery, but that budgets couldn’t pay for his parents to go along. “Will you go with him?” Selnow asked. “No, I’ll drop him off and someone from the hospital will meet him at [[de Gaulle Airport]].”
“So, this boy will undergo open-heart surgery without anyone to hold his hand and tell him in his Albanian language that he’ll be fine?” The nurse said, “That’s how it is, I’m sorry.”
Soon afterwards, WiRED International set up a program it called “Video Visit,” where a computer in [[Prishtina]] (Priština), where the parents remained, and a computer in the host country, where the children were being treated, could connect via the Internet. The connections allowed the parents and the children to speak on a regular basis and stay in touch during the children’s often extended treatments. WiRED International’s Video Visit wasn’t set up in time for the boy in the van, but it operated for many other children set off in the months that followed.
WiRED International’s mission became focused on medical and health education as a result of the clear needs evident in Kosovo. A year later, with a National Institutes of Health developmental grant, WiRED began HIV/AIDS education programs across Kenya and then in Sierra Leone. The work expanded to all medical and health concerns, and today through partnerships, WiRED programs are in several African countries and in parts of China, Central and South America, the Middle East, Melanesia and Eurasia.
In spring 2003 the State Department asked Selnow to travel to Baghdad with a representative of its U.S. Global Technology Corps to explore how WiRED could most effectively deliver medical training programs to Iraqi doctors. In June 2003, after reviewing field conditions and talking with U.S officials, Iraqi physicians and medical educators, WiRED launched the first technology-based medical training program in the country, starting with the opening of a facility in Iraq’s Medical City Center. Within 18 months the organization had set up 39 centers around Iraq. Several years later WiRED launched the country’s first telemedicine program. Technical problems with satellite availability in the war zone made that program difficult, and it never fully matured. WiRED’s work in Iraq ended in 2010, as the U.S. commitment was winding down.
In 2011, as WiRED’s ground programs expanded elsewhere, it began development of its own educational training materials. The program evolved, in 2013, into the Center for the Development and Distribution of Health Education Programs. This resource supplies medical and health education modules via the Internet and portable storage media. It allows partners or any interested NGO to store training modules on thumb drives and laptops and sync them to acquire updates. The result has been a broad distribution of health education programs, even in the most remote areas.
In 2014, WiRED has evolved into a health education hub operating in remote and resource-starved regions globally. WiRED collects intellectual content from physicians, nurses and medical educators from around the world. WiRED packages and translates it, when appropriate, and distributes it widely. This clearinghouse model has enabled many medical professionals to contribute to the program, and it has provided a source of health content for people in places isolated and often ignored.
== WiRED International’s Center for the Development and Distribution of Health Information == In 2011, WiRED International launched a virtual [http://www.wiredhealthresources.net Center] which draws intellectual content and resources from regions of abundance, processes it for new audiences and distributes that information to regions of scarcity. This project is funded in large part by [http://philanthropy.medtronic.com/ Medtronic Philanthropy].
The WiRED International e-library of more than 300 medical and health education modules enables physicians and nurses, patients, health workers and communities to address the prevention and treatment of both infectious and non-communicable disease in developing areas of the world. The more than 300 topics as diverse as maternal health and hand washing, rheumatic heart disease and Ebola, clean water strategies and home caregiver training.
In 2014 WiRED International expanded the global reach of its programs by creating a “Filling Station.” This is a tool that provides file synchronization (or syncing), whereby a person’s computer can upload data from a master file in an automatic process that adds new or changed material. Thus, the Filling Station allows instant updating of the entire community health education (CHE) e-library from any Internet access point in the world.
With these interactive training programs, communities and medical professionals alike can educate themselves through the material released on this website and also distributed on portable media for communities off the grid.
These training modules are developed by WiRED International’s team of physicians, medical editors, imagers and technicians along with a host of other medical experts. The team continually updates the existing material and creates new modules to provide a rich source of health information.
== Rapid Response Modules == [[File:WiRED International Ebola Module Screenshot.png|thumb|WiRED International Ebola Module Screenshot]] When a community health crisis occurs, WiRED International speeds the creation of a rapid response module and translates it into appropriate languages. Examples include: * [http://www.wiredhealthresources.net/mod-ebola.html Ebola] (translated into [http://www.wiredhealthresources.net/presentations/58-fr/story.html French]) * [http://www.wiredhealthresources.net/mod-malnutrition.html Severe Malnutrition] (translated into [http://www.wiredhealthresources.net/presentations/121-ab/story.html Arabic]) * [http://www.wiredhealthresources.net/mod-polio.html Polio] (translated into [http://www.wiredhealthresources.net/presentations/117-ab/story.html Arabic] and [http://www.wiredhealthresources.net/presentations/117-ar/story.html Armenian])

{{primary sources|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox Podcast | title = Writing Excuses | image = | caption = | host = [[Dan Wells (author)|Dan Wells]], [[Brandon Sanderson]], [[Howard Tayler]], [[Mary Robinette Kowal]] | picture format = | url = [http://www.writingexcuses.com/ www.writingexcuses.com] | rss = http://www.writingexcuses.com/feed/ | atom = | status = | began = 02/10/2008 | ended = | genre = | ratings = }}
'''Writing Excuses''' is a podcast hosted by authors [[Dan Wells (author)|Dan Wells]], [[Brandon Sanderson]], [[Mary Robinette Kowal]] and web cartoonist [[Howard Tayler]].
Promoted as "fifteen minutes long, because you're in a hurry, and we're not that smart",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.writingexcuses.com |title=Writing Excuses |publisher=Writing Excuses |date= |accessdate=2012-11-09}}</ref> the four hosts and guests discuss different topics involved in the creation and production of genre writing and webcomics. As of 2017, authors [[Wesley Chu]], [[Piper J. Drake]] and [[Mary Anne Mohanraj]] were added as secondary hosts, each having 1 show a month alongside different configurations of the primary hosts.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.writingexcuses.com/2017/01/01/12-1-variations-on-first-person/|title=12.1: Variations on First Person|last=Tayler|first=Howard|date=2017-01-01|website=Writing Excuses|access-date=2017-02-01}}</ref>
==Premise== Writing Excuses began in 2008 with three hosts – Sanderson, Tayler, and Wells – accompanied by Brandon's brother, Jordan Sanderson, who serves as producer. The show aims to cover a single writing-related topic in each podcast, in a format short enough to be listened to on a morning commute or during a lunch break. Adherence to a fifteen minute limit is not absolute, and ''Writing Excuses'' frequently runs to about 20 minutes.
The single topic is discussed in a back-and-forth by the hosts for roughly fifteen minutes. Given the authors' backgrounds in fantasy and science fiction there is a strong emphasis in those genres, but ''Writing Excuses'' covers a wide variety of topics intended to apply to fiction and creative arts generally. Halfway through the podcast the hosts introduce a book of the week, either a favorite of the hosts or one of their own works. Writing Excuses has been sponsored by [[Audible.com|Audible]] since October 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.writingexcuses.com/2009/10/25/writing-excuses-season-3-episode-22-idea-to-story/ |title=Season 3 Episode 22: Idea to Story |publisher=Writing Excuses |date= |accessdate=2012-11-09}}</ref> On numerous occasions, often at conventions, the hosts invite guest authors and industry professionals on board for podcast episodes.
After making a number of guest appearances, Mary Robinette Kowal joined the permanent cast as a new host at the beginning of season 6.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.writingexcuses.com/2011/06/05/writing-excuses-6-1-can-creativity-be-taught/ |title=6.1: Can Creativity be Taught? |publisher=Writing Excuses |date= |accessdate=2012-11-09}}</ref>
[[Wesley Chu]], [[Piper J. Drake]], and [[Mary Anne Mohanraj]] were added as secondary hosts at the beginning of series 12<ref name=":0" />
==''Shadows Beneath'' anthology== ''Shadows Beneath'', an anthology of four stories written by the members of ''Writing Excuses'', was published in 2014.<ref>{{cite book | title = Shadows Beneath: The Writing Excuses Anthology | authorlink1 = Dan Wells (author) | first1 = Dan | last1 = Wells | authorlink2 = Howard Tayler | first2 = Howard | last2 = Tayler | authorlink3 = Mary Robinette Kowal | first3 = Mary Robinette | last3 = Kowal | authorlink4 = Brandon Sanderson | first4 = Brandon | last4 = Sanderson | asin = B00LDOM8A2 | publisher = Dragonsteel Entertainment }}</ref> The anthology's bonus material is intended to show some of the processes of story creation. The stories were brainstormed on the podcast and the first drafts later critiqued; transcripts of the podcasts, along with the first drafts of the stories, are included.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://brandonsanderson.com/shadows-beneath/ | title = Shadows Beneath | website = brandonsanderson.com | first = Brandon | last = Sanderson | date = June 30, 2014 }}</ref> The stories are:
* ''I.E. Demon'', by [[Dan Wells (author)|Dan Wells]] * ''An Honest Death'', by [[Howard Tayler]] * ''A Fire in the Heavens'', by [[Mary Robinette Kowal]] * ''Sixth of the Dusk'', by [[Brandon Sanderson]]
==Awards== *[[Hugo Awards]] 2014 (season 8, nominated for [[Hugo Award for Best Related Work|Best Related Work]]) <ref name="Hugo14">{{cite web|url=http://www.thehugoawards.org/hugo-history/2014-hugo-awards/ |title=2014 Hugo Awards | publisher=World Science Fiction Society| accessdate=2014-04-20}}</ref> *Hugo Awards 2013 (season 7, winner for Best Related Work) <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehugoawards.org/2013/09/2013-hugo-award-winners/ |title=2013 Hugo Award Winners |publisher=World Science Fiction Society |accessdate=2013-02-09}}</ref> *Hugo Awards 2012 (season 6, nominated for Best Related Work)<ref name="Hugo12">{{cite web|url=http://www.thehugoawards.org/hugo-history/2012-hugo-awards/ |title=2012 Hugo Awards | publisher=World Science Fiction Society| accessdate=2014-04-20}}</ref> *Hugo Awards 2011 (season 4, nominated for Best Related Work) <ref name="Hugo11">{{cite web|url=http://www.thehugoawards.org/hugo-history/2011-hugo-awards/ |title=2011 Hugo Awards | publisher=World Science Fiction Society| accessdate=2014-04-20}}</ref> *[[Podcast Awards]] 2010 (nominated) <ref>{{cite web|author=One Technologies, LLC |url=http://www.podcastawards.com/ |title=PodCastAwards.com |publisher=PodCastAwards.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-09}}</ref> *[[Parsec Awards]] 2010 (winner for Best Podcast about Speculative Fiction Content Creation) <ref>[http://www.parsecawards.com/past-awards/2010-parsec-awards-winners-finalists/ "2010 Parsec Awards Winners & Finalists"]. parsecawards.com. Retrieved 2012-11-09</ref> *Parsec Awards 2009 (winner for Best Writing Related Podcast) <ref>[http://www.parsecawards.com/past-awards/2009-parsec-award-winners-finalists/ "2009 Parsec Award Winners & Finalists"]. parsecawards.com. Retrieved 2012-11-09</ref>
